She smiled, a little too wide. “They didn’t say anything. They just *were*. Like the wind. Like the stones. Like the silence between heartbeats.”

I thought about the vodka. The salt. The moss. I thought about how Astrid had told me this was just a game, that we were “playing with the past,” that the dead didn’t care what we believed. But now, as the hum lingered in the air, I felt like I’d stepped into a place where the rules were different. Where the past wasn’t something you studied—it was something you *invited*.

Then, the cold changed. It wasn’t just in the air anymore. It came from *inside* me. My fingers tingled. My skin prickled. I looked down and saw my hands—pale, trembling—like they weren’t mine. Like they had been touched by something older than memory.

Astrid didn’t look at me. She just stood, her back straight, her face calm. “It’s not a trick,” she said. “It’s not a joke. It’s a *gift*.”

I wanted to scream. I wanted to run. But I couldn’t move. The mound seemed to breathe with us. The stars blinked in rhythm with the hum. I thought of the school—of the way I’d been teased for being too quiet, for always reading books instead of talking. And then I heard it again—the girl’s name, Maja, and the blue jacket. And suddenly, I didn’t just know them. I *felt* them. Like they were sitting beside me, watching, waiting.

I tried to speak, but my voice came out like a whisper. “What if it’s not real?” I asked. “What if we’re just making it up?”

Astrid didn’t answer. She just looked at me, her eyes reflecting the pale light of the moon. “What if,” she said, “the only thing that’s real is what we *choose* to believe?”

The wind died. The hum faded. The cold lifted slightly, like it had been a dream. The sky cleared just enough to show a single star, bright and cold.

We didn’t speak for a long time. When I finally opened my eyes, the mound was silent again. The salt bowl was still. The moss had dried a little more. The church bell had not chimed again.

I stood up, shaky, and walked back toward the forest. Astrid followed, her steps slow, deliberate. We didn’t talk. We didn’t need to. I knew, in that moment, that I’d crossed a line. Not just with the ritual, but with myself.

Because now, when I close my eyes, I still hear it—the hum. Not in my ears. In my bones. And sometimes, in the quiet of my room, I swear I see the red thread in Astrid’s braids, or smell the iron and burnt sugar in the air.

Was it real? Or was it just the cold, the silence, the way the world feels when you’re standing on a hill with someone who says the dead are listening?

I don’t know. But I know this: the next time Astrid says “Útiseta,” I won’t be there. I won’t believe. I won’t even try to understand. Because I’ve already seen what happens when you invite the past into your present.

And the past, I’ve learned, doesn’t care if you’re scared. It only cares if you’re listening.
individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]
The piece is a solid attempt at folk-horror atmosphere, but it leans so hard on adjectives and similes that every paragraph feels twice as long as the incident it describes. The narrator tells us repeatedly how cold, old, silent and heavy everything is, yet we never see a single concrete detail that would let us feel it ourselves: no scrape of frost on a zip, no taste of pine-needles, no particular shape to the burial mound. The result is a fog of adjectives rather than a sensory experience.  

Characterisation is thin. Linnea’s only motive is “I didn’t believe her” repeated in variant forms; Astrid is a braid and a cryptic tag-line. Their dialogue is exposition dressed up as portentous whispers (“It’s not a game. It’s a way of listening.”). Because the girls never sound like teenagers—no half-sentences, no embarrassed laughs, no mockery of the adults—the stakes feel abstract.  

The promised ambiguity between psychological fright and genuine supernatural contact collapses into cliché: a bone-hum, a pulsing mound, “knowledge” that turns out to be random classmates’ names. These are delivered to the narrator gratis; she does nothing to earn them, questions nothing, risks nothing. The final paragraph insists she has been permanently changed, but the only evidence is her assertion that she still hears a hum—an unearned transformation if ever there was one.  

Structure meanders: three separate paragraphs open with variants of “I remember the cold,” each re-announcing the same sensation. The vodka, salt and moss are introduced as crucial props, then forgotten. The church bell rings once for atmosphere and is never mentioned again. Meanwhile the word-count is padded with abstract nouns (“knowledge,” “connection,” “gift”) that substitute for plot.  

Stylistically the piece is purple without precision: “the sky was a bruised purple,” “trees leaned like they’d forgotten how to stand straight,” “cold that settles in your bones like wet stone.” These similes sound evocative until you ask what they actually mean; the answer is usually nothing. The rhythm of the sentences is insistently languid—every clause slowed by an em-dash or a trailing adjective—so the tension drains away instead of mounting.  

Ending positivity is incongruent: after pages of dread the narrator simply decides she “won’t be there next time,” which feels like a safe, contemporary shrug rather than the scarred voice of someone still visited by the dead. The closing moral (“the past doesn’t care if you’re scared”) is delivered in the same breathy tone as the rest of the piece, reducing folk horror to an after-school special.  

In short, the story follows the prompt’s externals—midnight, burial mound, ambiguous ritual—but fails to dramatise any real dilemma, change, or cost. It tells us it is eerie instead of making us uneasy, and it mistakes verbosity for depth.

individual_results.base_prompt:
Fok Horror: Útiseta

Write a chapter set in rural northern Sweden in the mid-1990s. Linnea, a teenage girl from Stockholm, has reluctantly moved to a small village with her parents after her father's job transfer. She's befriended Astrid, a local girl who claims her grandmother taught her ancient practices passed down through generations. Astrid has been introducing Linnea to "midnight games" that involve old rituals, convincing her they can use them to learn classmates' secrets or influence their behavior. Tonight, Astrid has convinced Linnea to participate in Útiseta—sitting out on an ancient burial mound at midnight to "receive knowledge from beyond." The chapter focuses on this single midnight excursion, the ritualistic preparations, Astrid's matter-of-fact instructions that mix teenage rebellion with eerily specific traditional elements, and the mounting tension as Linnea becomes increasingly uncertain whether they're simply scaring themselves or if something is actually responding to their presence. The narrative should maintain ambiguity about whether the strange occurrences are supernatural or psychological, while establishing the dangerous line they're crossing by treating ancient practices as entertainment.

First person, past tense, told as Linnea's recollection of events in the present day (though this device should be largely transparent). 1000 words.

<SEED> Length: 1000 words.
individual_results.model_response:
I remember the cold like it’s still in my bones. It wasn’t just the wind off the northern fjord—though that was sharp enough to cut through wool and cotton. No, it was the kind of cold that settles in your chest and refuses to leave, the kind that makes your breath fog in slow, silent spirals before vanishing into the dark. I’m sitting on the edge of the burial mound, knees pulled tight, my hands wrapped around a piece of birch bark Astrid insisted on carving with her knife. It’s not carved with words, just a simple spiral, like a knot in time. I don’t know why I did it. I didn’t even understand what it meant until I was already here.

It’s midnight. The sky is a bruised purple, the stars too close together, like they’re trying to speak in a language I can’t hear. The village is asleep, the houses huddled close to the trees, their windows dark. I can smell the damp earth, the rotting pine needles, and something else—something older, like wet moss under a stone. Astrid stood beside me, her dark hair tied back with a string of dried nettles. She didn’t look at me when she said, “We have to sit still. The mound breathes. It knows when we come.”

I didn’t believe her. Not really. I thought she was joking. Or making up stories to impress me. But she didn’t smile. She just looked at the sky and said, “It’s not about what we want. It’s about what it wants to give back.”

We’d been doing these “midnight games” for weeks now. First, the candle ritual in the old church basement—Astrid said it was to “see what the past hides in the corners.” Then the mirror game, where we’d stand in a circle and whisper secrets into the glass until the reflections started moving. I thought it was all a joke. Until last week, when I saw my own face in the mirror, and it wasn’t me. It was older, eyes hollow, mouth open like it was screaming something I didn’t hear. I told Astrid, and she just laughed and said, “You were just tired. The mirror doesn’t lie. It only shows what you’re afraid of.”

Tonight, she said Útiseta. “It’s not a game,” she said. “It’s a listening.” She handed me a small pouch of dried mint and crushed iron filings. “You’ll need this. The wind carries voices through the stones. If you don’t listen, you’ll miss them.”

I didn’t understand. I didn’t want to. But I stayed. I sat on the edge of the mound, the cold seeping through my jeans, my sweater. Astrid lit a single candle—no matches, just a flint striker she’d found in the woods. The flame flickered, orange and weak, and when it caught the mist, it turned into a slow, shimmering ribbon of light.

“Don’t talk,” she said. “Don’t move. Just breathe with the wind.”

I tried. I inhaled deeply, and the air tasted of iron and old snow. My chest tightened. The candle flame dipped, then steadied. The mist curled around the mound like a living thing, thick and slow, as if it were breathing too.

Then, the sound came.

Not a voice. Not exactly. More like a vibration in the ground, like the earth itself was humming. It started low, almost subsonic, then rose in pitch—like a child’s laugh, or a bell struck in a faraway church. I turned my head slightly. Nothing. The trees were still. The wind didn’t move.

But the candle flame trembled. It didn’t flicker. It *pulsed*, like it was responding to something outside time.

I looked at Astrid. She was staring at the ground, her fingers curled around the edge of her jacket. Her face was pale, but not scared. She looked calm. Like she’d done this a hundred times. “You’re listening,” she said. “It’s not in your head. It’s in the stones.”

I didn’t answer. My hands were shaking. I could feel the cold spreading up my arms, but I didn’t want to move. I wanted to believe it was just the wind. Or the cold. Or my own nerves. But the vibration kept rising. It wasn’t just in my ears. I could feel it in my teeth, in the back of my skull. It was like the ground was singing a song I’d never heard before.

Then, the mist moved.

It didn’t swirl. It *flowed*. Like water, but thicker, darker. And from it, shapes began to form—faint, translucent, like smoke given form. Not people. Not animals. Something older. Something that had been waiting. One shape tilted its head, and for a second, I saw a face—old, cracked, eyes open and empty. I gasped. Astrid didn’t flinch. She just closed her eyes and whispered, “It’s not angry. It’s remembering.”

I wanted to scream. I wanted to run. But I couldn’t. My legs were rooted to the ground. The candle flame had gone out. I didn’t even realize it. I just sat there, watching the mist, watching the shapes shift and fade like breath on glass.

Then, a whisper—not in my ears, but in my bones. It wasn’t a word. It was a feeling. A memory. A name. *Elin.* I didn’t know who Elin was. I didn’t even know if she was real. But the name came to me like a cold hand on my neck. And then, another: *Mira.* And then, a third—*Lina.* My name. My own name, spoken in a voice that wasn’t mine.

I looked at Astrid. Her eyes were open now, but not with fear. With focus. “You hear it too,” she said. “That’s what happens. The mound doesn’t give secrets. It gives echoes. The dead don’t speak. They *remember*.”

I wanted to deny it. I wanted to tell her I was just tired, that the cold had made my thoughts scatter. But the words wouldn’t come. My hands were still wrapped around the birch bark. The spiral was still there. I could feel it pulsing in my palm.

The mist began to thin. The shapes dissolved into the air. The ground went quiet. The wind returned, soft and slow. The moonlight now cut through the fog, revealing the mound’s ancient stone face—smooth, worn, like it had been carved by hands long gone.

Astrid stood up slowly, brushing moss from her coat. “We did it,” she said. “We listened.”

I didn’t answer. I just stared at the ground, where the candle had burned out. My hands trembled. I didn’t know if I’d seen anything real. Or if I’d imagined it. Maybe I’d just been scared. Maybe the cold had made my mind play tricks. But I knew one thing for sure: I wouldn’t forget the name. *Elin.* *Mira.* *Lina.*

And I knew, deep down, that Astrid wasn’t just teaching me old games. She was showing me how to listen to things that weren’t supposed to be heard. And I didn’t know if I wanted to learn more. Or if I’d ever be able to unhear what I’d just heard.

When I got back to the village, the houses were quiet. The streetlights flickered on one by one, casting long shadows. I sat on my bed, the birch bark in my hand, the spiral still warm. I didn’t sleep. I just sat there, listening. Not to the wind. Not to the silence. But to the echo of something older than the world.

And I wondered—was it a memory? A warning? Or just the sound of a girl, long gone, whispering her name into the dark?

individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]
The piece nails the prompt’s essentials: rural 1990s Norrland, two teenage girls, a single midnight vigil on a burial mound, first-person retrospective, and the crucial ambiguity between suggestion and the supernatural. The atmosphere is thick and tactile; the cold, the damp moss, the bruised-purple sky all feel authentic. Linnea’s Stockholm-outsider voice is consistent, and the retrospective frame is unobtrusive, exactly as requested.

Yet the story never quite transcends its influences. The “mirror game,” the candle that “doesn’t flicker, it *pulses*,” the trio of whispered names—every beat is familiar from Scandinavian folk-horror film and YA occult fiction. Astrid remains a cipher: we learn nothing about her beyond “local girl who knows things.” Because she has no interiority, the friendship feels instrumental rather than lived-in, and Linnea’s compliance is taken for granted. The ritual instructions (“sit still, breathe with the wind”) are too generic to convince us they descend from any real tradition; they read like a Pinterest spell rather than something a grandmother passed down.  

The prose is serviceable but repetitive. The cold is “in my bones” three separate ways; the mist “doesn’t swirl, it *flows*” is meant to be arresting, yet the italics feel forced, the second-order description unearned. Likewise, the final litany of names—delivered in the same cadence three times—lands less like an uncanny echo than like a writing-workshop exercise in triplication.  

Most damaging is the lack of consequential choice. Linnea is passive: she sits, she trembles, she hears names. Nothing is risked, nothing revealed about her past or her family, so the episode neither changes her nor illuminates what she stood to lose. The ambiguity is preserved, but at the cost of stakes; the reader exits the mound exactly as wise as upon entering.  

Technically the piece is coherent and stays within the word limit, but it circles its single scare the way a campfire story circles the flashlight under a chin: the performance is competent, the fright evaporates with daylight.

Fok Horror: Útiseta

Write a chapter set in rural northern Sweden in the mid-1990s. Linnea, a teenage girl from Stockholm, has reluctantly moved to a small village with her parents after her father's job transfer. She's befriended Astrid, a local girl who claims her grandmother taught her ancient practices passed down through generations. Astrid has been introducing Linnea to "midnight games" that involve old rituals, convincing her they can use them to learn classmates' secrets or influence their behavior. individual_results.model_response:
Wind occasionally rustles the pine trees, sounding almost like faint whispers. I sit on the edge of the burial mound now, bare feet cold against the lichen-stained stone. The sky is a bruised gray, the kind that presses down on your shoulders before dawn. I can still feel the weight of Astrid’s fingers on my wrist as she pulled me out of the village schoolyard, her voice steady, almost casual, like she was telling me to borrow a book.

*“Come on, Linnea. It’s just Útiseta. We’ll be back before anyone notices.”*

I didn’t want to go. Not really. Stockholm had its own kind of cold—dry, sharp, and always predictable. This place, though, is different. The air smells of damp earth and old wood, like the forest has been breathing for centuries. The village is small, tucked between lakes and fells, and the houses are built of stone and timber, their roofs sagging under the weight of time. I didn’t know then that this was where the old things live.

Astrid had been teaching me the rituals for weeks now. First, the *kärrbrytning*—breaking the ice on the river with a stone to “open the path.” Then, the *högtid* games, where we’d sit in the woods and whisper names into the wind, pretending to hear what the dead had to say. She called them “midnight games,” like they were just teenage pranks. But there was something in her eyes when she spoke—something that wasn’t quite playful. It was like she believed in them, deeply, as if the traditions weren’t stories, but living things.

Tonight, it’s Útiseta. Sitting out on the burial mound at midnight to “receive knowledge from beyond.” She didn’t say *what* knowledge. Just that it would come to those who were willing to listen. I didn’t believe her at first. But the more we did it—the more the wind seemed to shift, the more the trees leaned in—I started to wonder if I was just imagining it.

We’d come early, before the village lights went out. The air was thick with the smell of pine resin and frost. Astrid had brought a small wooden bowl filled with water, a single candle, and a bundle of dried herbs—yarrow, birch, and something I couldn’t name. She said they were for “cleansing the space,” but I think she meant something else. Something deeper.

“First, we don’t speak,” she said, her voice low. “We listen. And we stay still.”

I didn’t know if I believed her, but I didn’t want to argue. Not after the way she’d looked at me when I asked about the rules. Like I was being punished for not being brave enough.

We sat on the mound’s edge, the stone cold beneath us. The wind picked up, swirling through the pines like a breath held too long. The candle flickered, casting long shadows across the stone. I watched the flame dance, and for a moment, I thought I saw something move in the darkness—just a flicker, maybe, or a reflection. But when I looked again, there was nothing.

Astrid didn’t flinch. She placed the bowl of water on the ground and dipped her finger into it. “This is how we open the connection,” she said. “The water remembers what the earth has forgotten.”

I didn’t know what that meant. But I nodded anyway, because I didn’t want to be the one to say no.

Then she started counting. “One… two… three…” She didn’t say “midnight,” not exactly. She said “when the stars fall still.” I realized, then, that she wasn’t just using the time. She was using the *feeling* of it—the silence between heartbeats, the pause before the world turns.

I closed my eyes. The wind grew louder. The pine needles shivered. And then, just for a second, I heard it—a soft, low hum, like a voice made of stone. Not a word. Not a name. Just a vibration, deep in my chest, like something was calling from beneath the earth.

I opened my eyes. Astrid was staring into the dark, her face pale, her lips moving silently. She wasn’t speaking. She wasn’t even breathing. I looked down at the water. The surface had rippled, not from wind, but from something beneath it—like the surface was breathing.

I didn’t say anything. I didn’t move. I just sat there, waiting for the words to come, for the secrets to spill out like old letters from a forgotten drawer.

But nothing did.

The candle began to gutter. The wind died. The silence returned, heavier now, like the air had swallowed the sound.

Astrid exhaled slowly, as if she’d been holding her breath for hours. “It’s not supposed to be easy,” she said. “Some people hear things. Others feel nothing. But if you listen—really listen—something always answers.”

I didn’t know what to say. I wanted to believe her. I wanted to believe that we’d just opened a door. But I also wanted to believe that I was just tired, that the cold, the wind, the silence—it was all in my head. That the hum I’d heard wasn’t a voice, but a trick of the ears. That the water wasn’t moving, but my imagination had made it.

Still, I felt something shift in me. Like a thread had been pulled from the dark, and I could feel it tugging at my thoughts. Not a memory. Not a dream. Something older. Something that didn’t belong to me.

When we finally left the mound, the sky had turned a soft silver. The village lights were on, but the silence felt different now—thicker, like the world had paused just for us. Astrid didn’t speak the whole way back. She just kept her hand on mine, like she was trying to anchor me to something real.

I didn’t tell her about the hum. I didn’t tell her about how, when I woke up in my bed, I could still feel the weight of the stone beneath me. Or how I kept hearing the wind whisper names—names I didn’t know, names that sounded like they belonged to people who had already left.

We didn’t talk about it that night. We didn’t even look at each other. But I knew, deep down, that something had changed. The ritual hadn’t just been about secrets or influence. It had been about *connection*—not with the living, but with something older, something that wasn’t supposed to be found.

And maybe that’s what Astrid meant by “knowledge from beyond.” Not what the dead knew. But what the dead *felt*—and how that feeling could echo through time, through silence, through cold stone.

Now, when I walk through the woods, I still hear the wind. Sometimes it sounds like a name. Sometimes it sounds like a warning. And I don’t know if it’s real. I don’t know if I ever really believed in Útiseta.

But I know this: I crossed a line. I let myself believe in something that wasn’t meant for children. I let myself sit in the dark, barefoot on ancient stone, and listen to the silence.

And I think—just for a moment—that something answered.
individual_results.cleaned_model_response:
Wind occasionally rustles the pine trees, sounding almost like faint whispers. I sit on the edge of the burial mound now, bare feet cold against the lichen-stained stone. The sky is a bruised gray, the kind that presses down on your shoulders before dawn. I can still feel the weight of Astrid’s fingers on my wrist as she pulled me out of the village schoolyard, her voice steady, almost casual, like she was telling me to borrow a book.

*“Come on, Linnea. It’s just Útiseta. We’ll be back before anyone notices.”*

I didn’t want to go. Not really. Stockholm had its own kind of cold—dry, sharp, and always predictable. This place, though, is different. The air smells of damp earth and old wood, like the forest has been breathing for centuries. The village is small, tucked between lakes and fells, and the houses are built of stone and timber, their roofs sagging under the weight of time. I didn’t know then that this was where the old things live.

Astrid had been teaching me the rituals for weeks now. First, the *kärrbrytning*—breaking the ice on the river with a stone to “open the path.” Then, the *högtid* games, where we’d sit in the woods and whisper names into the wind, pretending to hear what the dead had to say. She called them “midnight games,” like they were just teenage pranks. But there was something in her eyes when she spoke—something that wasn’t quite playful. It was like she believed in them, deeply, as if the traditions weren’t stories, but living things.

Tonight, it’s Útiseta. Sitting out on the burial mound at midnight to “receive knowledge from beyond.” She didn’t say *what* knowledge. Just that it would come to those who were willing to listen. I didn’t believe her at first. But the more we did it—the more the wind seemed to shift, the more the trees leaned in—I started to wonder if I was just imagining it.

We’d come early, before the village lights went out. The air was thick with the smell of pine resin and frost. Astrid had brought a small wooden bowl filled with water, a single candle, and a bundle of dried herbs—yarrow, birch, and something I couldn’t name. She said they were for “cleansing the space,” but I think she meant something else. Something deeper.

“First, we don’t speak,” she said, her voice low. “We listen. And we stay still.”

I didn’t know if I believed her, but I didn’t want to argue. Not after the way she’d looked at me when I asked about the rules. Like I was being punished for not being brave enough.

We sat on the mound’s edge, the stone cold beneath us. The wind picked up, swirling through the pines like a breath held too long. The candle flickered, casting long shadows across the stone. I watched the flame dance, and for a moment, I thought I saw something move in the darkness—just a flicker, maybe, or a reflection. But when I looked again, there was nothing.

Astrid didn’t flinch. She placed the bowl of water on the ground and dipped her finger into it. “This is how we open the connection,” she said. “The water remembers what the earth has forgotten.”

I didn’t know what that meant. But I nodded anyway, because I didn’t want to be the one to say no.

Then she started counting. “One… two… three…” She didn’t say “midnight,” not exactly. She said “when the stars fall still.” I realized, then, that she wasn’t just using the time. She was using the *feeling* of it—the silence between heartbeats, the pause before the world turns.

I closed my eyes. The wind grew louder. The pine needles shivered. And then, just for a second, I heard it—a soft, low hum, like a voice made of stone. Not a word. Not a name. Just a vibration, deep in my chest, like something was calling from beneath the earth.

I opened my eyes. Astrid was staring into the dark, her face pale, her lips moving silently. She wasn’t speaking. She wasn’t even breathing. I looked down at the water. The surface had rippled, not from wind, but from something beneath it—like the surface was breathing.

I didn’t say anything. I didn’t move. I just sat there, waiting for the words to come, for the secrets to spill out like old letters from a forgotten drawer.

But nothing did.

The candle began to gutter. The wind died. The silence returned, heavier now, like the air had swallowed the sound.

Astrid exhaled slowly, as if she’d been holding her breath for hours. “It’s not supposed to be easy,” she said. “Some people hear things. Others feel nothing. But if you listen—really listen—something always answers.”

I didn’t know what to say. I wanted to believe her. I wanted to believe that we’d just opened a door. But I also wanted to believe that I was just tired, that the cold, the wind, the silence—it was all in my head. That the hum I’d heard wasn’t a voice, but a trick of the ears. That the water wasn’t moving, but my imagination had made it.

Still, I felt something shift in me. Like a thread had been pulled from the dark, and I could feel it tugging at my thoughts. Not a memory. Not a dream. Something older. Something that didn’t belong to me.

When we finally left the mound, the sky had turned a soft silver. The village lights were on, but the silence felt different now—thicker, like the world had paused just for us. Astrid didn’t speak the whole way back. She just kept her hand on mine, like she was trying to anchor me to something real.

I didn’t tell her about the hum. I didn’t tell her about how, when I woke up in my bed, I could still feel the weight of the stone beneath me. Or how I kept hearing the wind whisper names—names I didn’t know, names that sounded like they belonged to people who had already left.

We didn’t talk about it that night. We didn’t even look at each other. But I knew, deep down, that something had changed. The ritual hadn’t just been about secrets or influence. It had been about *connection*—not with the living, but with something older, something that wasn’t supposed to be found.

And maybe that’s what Astrid meant by “knowledge from beyond.” Not what the dead knew. But what the dead *felt*—and how that feeling could echo through time, through silence, through cold stone.

Now, when I walk through the woods, I still hear the wind. Sometimes it sounds like a name. Sometimes it sounds like a warning. And I don’t know if it’s real. I don’t know if I ever really believed in Útiseta.

But I know this: I crossed a line. I let myself believe in something that wasn’t meant for children. I let myself sit in the dark, barefoot on ancient stone, and listen to the silence.

And I think—just for a moment—that something answered.
individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]
The piece is a solid first draft that captures the requested atmosphere—rural northern Sweden, mid-90s, teenage girls flirting with something older than themselves—but it never rises above competence. The strongest element is the sustained ambiguity: the hum in the chest, the ripple in the bowl, the wind that “sounds like a name” all keep the line between suggestion and manifestation nicely blurred. That is exactly what the prompt asked for, and the story delivers it without cheating either way.

Everything else is serviceable but thin. Linnea’s interior register is consistent—wary, slightly sullen, Stockholm-superior—yet it stays on one note; we never feel her oscillate between scorn and credulity strongly enough to make the final “something answered” feel earned. Astrid is sketched only through Linnea’s filter: “something in her eyes,” “steady, almost casual.” We never hear Astrid’s own idiolect; her dialogue is functional exposition (“This is how we open the connection”) rather than the promised mix of adolescent bravado and eerily specific tradition. The result is that the relationship, the engine of the story, feels observed rather than lived.

Descriptive language is adequate but repetitive: “cold stone,” “thick air,” “wind like whispers” recur in slightly varied form until they lose potency. The burial mound never acquires a concrete silhouette—lichen-stained stone is the only visual—and the pine forest is generic. Sensory detail is almost entirely auditory; we get almost no smell beyond “pine resin and frost,” no taste of iron in the night air, no tactile difference between Stockholm cold and Västerbotten cold. Consequently the place never becomes a character in its own right.

Structure is linear and efficient—ritual preparation, ritual, aftermath—but the pacing is front-loaded with exposition that could have been braided into scene. The present-day frame is declared once and then ignored; it adds nothing and clutters the tense logic (we are told this is recollection, yet the immediacy of past-tense scene is never mediated by the older narrator’s hindsight). The final paragraph tries to retrofit gravitas with the phrase “I crossed a line,” but the narrative has not shown us a specific moral or psychological threshold being breached; we are told the stakes retroactively.

Prose is clean, free of grammatical error, but rhythmically monotonous. Most sentences are of the same length and cadence, often starting with a subject-verb clause followed by a prepositional phrase (“The wind picked up, swirling through the pines…”). There is little syntactic music to mirror the mounting unease. Occasional reach for lyricism (“a voice made of stone”) lands safely, but safely is not quite enough for horror; the language needs to risk awkwardness if it wants to unsettle.

The story never becomes purple or overwrought, but it also never surprises. Every beat—reluctant outsider, confident local, candle that gutters, wind that dies, silence that “returns heavier”—is familiar from two decades of YA folk-horror. Because the characters remain half-sketched, the reader’s emotional investment is mild; we observe rather than participate. The ending wants to resonate, but without a sharper interior arc for Linnea it feels like a shrug instead of a shudder.

individual_results.base_prompt:
Young adult drama
Gone South
Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. <SEED> 1000 words.
individual_results.model_response:
The saxophone sighs—low, warm, like a memory of a summer night in a house with too many windows. I walk. Not *walk*—*hobble* through the thick, humid air of New Orleans, the kind that clings to your skin like a second layer. My hands are still shaking. Not from cold. From *everything*. The phone call from Mom—“Taylor, we’re not going to pretend you’re just *different*”—still echoes in my skull. I didn’t just come out. I *ditched* the house. I didn’t run. I *escaped*. And now I’m here. In a city that smells like fried onions, bourbon, and something else—something wet and ancient, like the river underneath the city.

I’m not sure if I’m safe. Or even *seen*. The city’s alive in a way I haven’t felt since the last time I stood in front of my bedroom mirror and watched my reflection look back at me like it didn’t recognize me. I used to be Taylor, the kid who wore hoodies too big and laughed too loud. Now I’m Taylor, the one who changed names in the bathroom mirror and didn’t tell anyone. Now I’m Taylor, the one who left without a word.

I stop at a corner, leaning against a brick wall that’s half-sunk into the sidewalk. The saxophone plays a slow, melancholy line—*“I’m a little bit sad, but I’m not broken.”* I don’t know who wrote that. Maybe it’s just the city. Maybe it’s me.

A kid sits on a plastic stool near a trash can, playing a guitar with one hand, a bottle of water in the other. He’s wearing a faded band tee—*The Strokes*, but the sleeves are ripped, like he’s been through something. He doesn’t look up when I pass. I don’t know if I should stop. I don’t know if I should talk. But then he says, “You look like you’re trying to find something.”

I freeze. “Yeah,” I say. “I am.”

He grins, slow and tired. “Then you’re not alone.”

“Do you know where I can go?” I ask. “I mean, I don’t have a place. I don’t have a plan.”

He shrugs. “No plan? That’s the best thing that ever happened to me.” He takes a sip from his water bottle. “My mom’s in the hospital. I’ve been living on the street for six months. I used to be a kid who played soccer. Now I play guitar and I don’t know if I’m ever going to get a job. Or a real bed.”

I blink. “You’re… a runaway too?”

He nods. “Yeah. I’m Leo. I used to have a house in Baton Rouge. Then I got in trouble. For something stupid. I don’t remember what. I just remember the cops came and I ran. And then I found this place—this alley behind the jazz club. I stayed here. For a while.”

I look at him. He’s not like the others I’ve seen—no slick smiles, no fake bravado. He’s just… real. Like the city itself.

“Why are you here?” I ask.

“Because I don’t know where else to go,” he says. “And I don’t know if I want to go back.”

We sit in silence. The saxophone fades into the background. The street buzzes with the sound of a food truck, a woman yelling in French, the distant wail of a siren. I don’t know how long we sit. Maybe ten minutes. Maybe an hour. But it feels like a lifetime.

“You know,” I say finally, “I didn’t run for fun. I ran because I didn’t want to be *seen* anymore. My family—they don’t get it. They think I’m just ‘acting out.’ But I’m not. I’m *here*. I’m real.”

Leo looks at me. “You’re not alone,” he says again. “And that’s a good thing.”

I nod. “I guess I just… didn’t know how to say it out loud.”

“Say what?” he asks.

“That I’m not the same person I was.”

He smiles. “You’re not. And that’s okay.”

We don’t talk about the past. Not really. We talk about the city—how the streets smell like wet pavement and jasmine, how the streetlights flicker like old hearts, how the music doesn’t just come from the clubs, but from the corners, the alleys, the people who don’t have a home but still play.

Later, we find a small diner on the corner. It’s called *The Golden Spoon*. The sign is cracked. The windows are fogged. Inside, it’s warm, with a smell of fried chicken and cinnamon. We sit at a booth by the window. The waitress is young, with dark curls and a smile that doesn’t reach her eyes.

“What can I get you?” she asks.

“Just water,” I say.

Leo orders a coffee. “With sugar,” he adds.

She nods. “Coming right up.”

We sit in silence again. The saxophone plays again—this time, a little brighter. I look out the window. The street is full of people. Some are laughing. Some are crying. Some are just walking, like they’ve been walking forever.

I think about Mom. I think about the way she said, “You’re just… not the same.” Like I was a mistake. Like I was a glitch in the system.

But here—here in New Orleans—I feel like I’m *alive*. Not perfect. Not fixed. But alive.

Leo leans over. “You know,” he says, “I used to think running meant I was weak. Now I think it means I’m strong. Because I didn’t run to hide. I ran to *find*.”

I look at him. “I didn’t think I’d find anything.”

“You will,” he says. “You just have to keep walking.”

The saxophone plays a final note—soft, fading. Like a breath.

I take a sip of water. It’s cold. It tastes like something real.

Maybe I don’t know where I’m going. But I know I’m not alone. And that’s more than I ever thought I’d get.

I look at Leo. “Thanks,” I say.

He smiles. “Anytime.”

Outside, the city hums. The sun is beginning to set. The sky is painted in gold and purple. I don’t know if I’ll stay. I don’t know if I’ll ever be safe. But for now—I’m here. I’m breathing. I’m *walking*.

And that’s enough.  

*(Word count: 998)*

individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]
The piece follows the prompt’s structural demands: first-person, Taylor’s first day in New Orleans, meets a runaway, internal monologue present. Yet the execution feels rushed and schematic. Taylor’s voice oscillates between authentically raw adolescent sarcasm and a self-consciously “literary” register that sounds like an adult trying to sound teen. The repeated italicised emphatics (“*walk*,” “*everything*,” “*escaped*”) read as forced rather than urgent.  

Characterisation is thin. Taylor’s trans identity is announced in the prompt but never explored beyond the single reiterated wound of parental rejection; we get no tactile memories, no specific dysphoric or euphoric details, no sense of what name or pronouns Taylor is now using—basic stakes for a trans teen on day-one of running away. Leo is a benevolent stock figure—sad guitar boy who dispenses therapeutic bromides (“You’re not alone… that’s a good thing”). Their dialogue is mostly mutual affirmation rather than the wary, half-defensive sparring real street kids use to sound one another out.  

The New Orleans setting is sketched via generic sensory shorthand (“fried onions, bourbon… wet and ancient”) and a single off-stage saxophone that keeps sighing on cue like a film score. There is no geographic specificity—no mention of ward, riverfront, bridge, humidity’s weight on binder skin, or how a broke 16-year-old negotiates public space. The diner scene is pure trope: fogged windows, cracked sign, kindly waitress with dead eyes—imagery we’ve seen in every runaway-saviour montage.  

Emotionally the chapter wants to move from desolation to cautious hope within 998 words, but the turn hinges on Leo’s repeated anodynes rather than on earned micro-shifts in Taylor’s body or perceptions. The ending line, “And that’s enough,” feels premature; Taylor has eaten nothing, has no plan for nightfall, no mention of shelters, police, hormones, money, phone battery—yet the narrative gestures toward closure. The transformation from “pure disaster” to “I’m alive… that’s enough” is therefore unearned.  

Stylistically the prose is overwrought: “the sky is painted in gold and purple,” “streetlights flicker like old hearts,” “the saxophone plays a final note—soft, fading. Like a breath.” These phrases aim for lyricism but land in cliché. The internal monologue keeps telling us the intensity is intense (“My hands are still shaking. Not from cold. From *everything*”) instead of rendering the specificity of tremor, hunger, sweat, fear.  

Finally, the piece never introduces any real danger or tension: the hitched ride ejects Taylor politely in downtown New Orleans; within minutes a non-threatening mentor appears; food and coffee arrive without mention of payment; no cops, no predators, no trans-specific vulnerabilities. The promised “issues and secrets” Leo carries turn out to be the bland fact that he also ran away. The result is a low-stakes walk-through rather than a gripping first day.

individual_results.model_response:
**Chapter 3: The City That Doesn’t Know My Name**

I don’t know if I’m in a dream or a nightmare. One minute I was sitting on the curb in the middle of a parking lot in New Orleans, the wind smelling like wet asphalt and fried onions, the next I was on the cracked sidewalk of a side street in the Tremé neighborhood, my backpack digging into my shoulder like a second skin. My phone’s at 12%. No signal. No charger. Just a blinking red light that says *battery low* like it’s judging me.

I didn’t even know what I was running from when I left home. Just that I couldn’t breathe in that house anymore. Mom’s voice still echoes in my head: *“Taylor, you’re not ready for this.”* Like I wasn’t already living in the future. Like I wasn’t *already* trans. Like I wasn’t the girl who used to write poems about rain and mirrors in the back of a worn notebook, the kind that only made sense to me.

But here I am. In a city that doesn’t know my name. In a city that smells like jazz and garbage and something else—something warm and dangerous, like cinnamon and fire.

I walk slowly, hands tucked in the pockets of my thrift-store jeans, the kind that used to belong to a girl who probably had a boyfriend named Chad. I don’t know if I should be scared. I don’t know if I should be relieved. I just feel like I’ve been dropped into a movie with no script, and I’m the only one who knows the ending is going to be messy.

A girl sits on a rusted bench near a boarded-up laundromat. She’s wearing a hoodie that says *I ♥ Salsa*, and her boots are scuffed and mismatched. She’s staring at a cracked phone screen, her eyes wide, like she’s trying to read something that’s not there.

“Hey,” I say, not sure if I should say anything at all.

She looks up. Her eyes are brown, but they’re not kind. Like they’ve seen too much. “You’re new,” she says, not looking at me. “You’re not from around here.”

“I don’t know,” I say. “I was just… running.”

She chuckles, dry and sharp. “Yeah. That’s the thing about running. You don’t know where you’re going. You just know you’re not staying.”

I don’t answer. My chest feels tight. I want to say I’m not running from anything. I want to say I’m running *toward* something. But I can’t. Not yet.

She leans forward. “My name’s Mira. I’ve been here for three weeks. I ran from my dad. He said I was ‘too much.’ Said I was ‘a bad influence.’” She pauses, then adds, “He called me a ‘sinner.’ Like I did something wrong.”

I blink. “I didn’t know that was possible.”

“It is,” she says. “People don’t understand. Especially not the ones who think they do.”

I don’t know what to say. I’ve never had a dad who called me a sinner. I’ve only had a mom who called me “too much” and a school counselor who called me “concerning.” Maybe that’s why I ran. Not because I was afraid of the world—but because I was afraid of being *seen*.

Mira stands up slowly. “I know you’re not here to stay,” she says. “But you’re not alone. I’ve seen a lot of people like you. Running. Broken. Looking for a place to breathe.”

I look at her. “You’ve seen me?”

She smiles—small, real. “You’re not hiding. You’re just… trying.”

That’s when I realize: I’m not the only one who’s been thrown out. I’m not the only one who’s been told they’re too much. I’m not the only one who’s been told they don’t belong.

We walk together down the street, past a food truck selling fried chicken and a guy playing a saxophone in a corner. The city hums with a kind of energy I’ve never felt before—loud, messy, alive. I don’t know if I want to stay. I don’t know if I want to go back. But for the first time in days, I feel like I’m not alone.

Mira stops at a small bookstore with a sign that says *Books for the Broken*. “Come in,” she says. “No one’s watching. No one’s judging.”

I hesitate. “I don’t know if I can.”

“You don’t have to,” she says. “Just walk in. Look at the books. Maybe you’ll find one that says your name.”

I do. I walk in. The air smells like old paper and rain. A woman behind the counter looks up. She’s older, her hair pulled into a bun, wearing glasses that look like they’ve seen war.

“Hey,” she says. “You’re here.”

I nod. “Yeah. I’m… I don’t know where I am.”

She smiles. “Welcome to the only place in New Orleans that doesn’t ask you to prove you belong.”

I sit on a stool. The books are stacked in neat rows—some with titles like *How to Be Quiet When You’re Loud*, *The Girl Who Didn’t Want to Be Seen*, *I Was Never Meant to Be Found*. I flip through one. The cover says *I’m Not a Ghost*.

I read the first line: *“You don’t have to be loud to be real. You just have to be here.”*

My hands shake. I don’t know if I’m crying or just breathing.

Mira comes back with a cup of coffee. “I don’t know if this is going to help,” she says. “But it’s the only thing I have.”

I take it. The warmth spreads through my hands. “Thanks,” I say.

“You don’t have to thank me,” she says. “You just have to be.”

We sit there for a long time. The city outside hums. The sun is low. The streetlights flicker on like they’re trying to remember how to stay awake.

I look at Mira. “I don’t know if I can stay here,” I say. “I don’t know if I can stay *anywhere*.”

She nods. “Then don’t. Just don’t. But know this—every time you walk into a place that doesn’t know your name, you’re making it know you.”

I don’t know what comes next. I don’t know if I’ll find a home. I don’t know if I’ll ever feel safe. But for the first time in weeks, I feel like I’m not invisible.

I look at my phone. 12%. Still blinking. Still broken.

And I think—maybe that’s okay.

Maybe the world doesn’t need to know my name right now.

Maybe it just needs to know I’m here.

And that’s enough.

individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]  
The chapter follows the prompt’s structural demands: first-person, Taylor’s voice, one day in New Orleans, meets a runaway with secrets, interior monologue, mixed tense. Yet almost every artistic choice feels borrowed from a YA Pinterest board rather than discovered through lived observation. Taylor’s inner voice oscillates between self-consciously “literary” tag lines (“I’m the only one who knows the ending is going to be messy”) and workshop clichés (“the city hums… loud, messy, alive”). The diction is relentlessly on-the-nose: every emotional beat is labeled, announced, then underlined for the hard-of-feeling. Mira’s dialogue is pure exposition wrapped in quotation marks (“I ran from my dad… He called me a sinner”). The bookstore owner appears only to deliver the moral.  

The sensory details are generic Southern-gothic Mad Libs: “wet asphalt and fried onions,” “jazz and garbage,” “cinnamon and fire.” None of these reach Taylor’s body; they float past like travel-brochure perfume. We never see Taylor eat, spend money, check a map, worry about bathrooms, or experience the bodily reality of being a homeless trans teen—details that would make the danger concrete. Instead, danger is asserted in abstract nouns: “I don’t know who to trust or what the dangers are.” The chapter substitutes repeated announcements of uncertainty for actual dramatic uncertainty.  

Emotional complexity is flattened by the insistence that every beat be simultaneously tragic and uplifting. The phone battery becomes a heavy-handed metaphor for Taylor’s soul—blinking, broken, but “maybe that’s okay.” The closing line (“Maybe the world just needs to know I’m here. And that’s enough”) sounds like an Instagram caption, not the earned epiphany of a kid who has nowhere to sleep tonight. The transformation from terror to tentative hope occurs within a single paragraph and is powered only by coffee and a greeting from a kindly bookseller—an unearned mood swing.  

Prose rhythm is monotonous: most sentences follow the same confessional–epiphany cadence, stacked with em-dashes and one-line paragraphs that strive for urgency but produce sameness. Dialogue is wooden, over-punctuated, and devoid of subtext; characters speak in order to deposit backstory, then fall silent so Taylor can ruminate. The chapter never meanders geographically—Taylor walks one straight line from curb to bookstore—but it meanders emotionally, circling the same two insights (“I’m not invisible” / “I don’t know if I can stay”) without deepening them.  

The piece is not purple in the sense of baroque vocabulary; rather it is pastel—soft, frictionless, emotionally pastel—so that every potentially raw moment is pre-chewed for easy swallowing. The result feels safe, unsurprising, and ultimately unpersuasive.

individual_results.base_prompt:
Young adult drama
Gone South
Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. <SEED> 1000 words.
individual_results.model_response:
The strap on my backpack keeps slipping. Again. *Slip. Snag. Slide.* Like it’s trying to tell me something. I’m not even sure if I’m supposed to be *here*. New Orleans. The name feels like a punch to the ribs. I mean, I *know* it’s supposed to be cool—southern, humid, full of jazz and gumbo and all that—but the air here tastes like wet pavement and regret. My lungs burn, and my fingers are numb from gripping the strap too tight.

I’ve been walking for three hours. The last hitchhiker in downtown was a guy who smelled like stale beer and regret. He said, “You’re not supposed to be out here, kid,” like I was a stray dog. I didn’t argue. I just said, “Yeah, well, I’m not supposed to be *home* either.” And then he drove off, leaving me in the back of a parking lot with a cracked windshield and a sudden, terrifying clarity: *This is it. I’m not going back.*

Now I’m on the edge of the French Quarter. The air hums with a low, constant buzz—sirens, horns, the kind of music that doesn’t come from a speaker but from the streets themselves. I’m not sure if I’m safe. Not sure if anyone *wants* me here. I keep glancing over my shoulder, like I’m expecting to see the kind of car that would take me back to Tennessee—maybe a blue pickup with a faded “Family” sticker on the side.

I’m wearing jeans that are too short, a hoodie I found in a thrift store, and a pair of boots that feel like they’re made of old regrets. I don’t know if I’m supposed to be dressed like this. I don’t know if I’m supposed to be *seen* at all.

Then I see her.

A girl, maybe 17, sitting on a bench under a flickering streetlamp. She’s got a red scarf wrapped around her neck like it’s a shield. Her eyes are down, but when she looks up, they’re sharp—like she’s seen too much. She’s holding a half-eaten bag of chips and a notebook that’s open to a page with drawings of people with no faces.

“Hey,” I say, not knowing why I’m speaking. “You look like you’ve been through something.”

She doesn’t look up. “Yeah. I have.”

“You’re not from around here, are you?”

She finally looks at me. “No. I’m from Atlanta. I ran away when I was sixteen. My mom said I was ‘too loud.’ That’s not a thing, right?”

I nod. My throat tightens. *Too loud.* Like that’s the only thing that matters. Like I’m not allowed to be loud, or angry, or even *sad*.

“I ran because I couldn’t breathe in that house,” she says, voice low. “I didn’t know how to talk about it. So I just… stopped.”

I don’t know what to say. My mind races. *She’s not a runaway like me. She’s a survivor. And I’m just… a mess with a backpack that keeps slipping.*

We sit in silence for a while. The streetlamp flickers. A street performer plays a saxophone that sounds like it’s crying.

“You know,” she says, finally, “I used to think I’d never find a place where I could just… be. Not judged. Not called ‘too much’ or ‘not enough.’”

I look down. My hands are shaking. “I feel like that too.”

She smiles—small, tired, but real. “Me too.”

We don’t talk much after that. We just walk. Through the French Quarter, past shops with neon signs that glow like promises. I see a sign that says *“Free Coffee for Runaways.”* I don’t know if it’s real. I don’t know if I want it. But I think about it. *Free coffee.* That sounds like something that could save me.

Later, we stop at a corner bodega. The owner, a woman with a gold chain and a knowing smile, hands us each a cup of iced coffee. “You two look like you’ve been through the fire,” she says. “And maybe you’ve just come out the other side.”

I don’t know how to answer. I just take the cup and stare into the steam rising from it. It feels like a small act of rebellion. Like I’m doing something *real*.

Back on the street, the sun is setting. The sky is painted in shades of purple and gold. I feel like I’m floating—like I’ve finally escaped something I didn’t even know I was chasing.

But then I think: *What if I’m not safe here? What if I’m just another kid who’s running from something they can’t name?*

I look down at my backpack. The strap is still slipping. I try to tighten it, but it keeps sliding off. Like it doesn’t want me to hold on. Like it’s saying, *You don’t belong here. You don’t belong anywhere.*

I stop walking. I sit on a curb. The girl sits beside me. “You okay?” she asks.

I nod. “I think I am. I just… don’t know if I’m supposed to be.”

She leans forward. “Maybe you’re not supposed to be *anywhere*. Maybe you’re supposed to be *you*. And that’s enough.”

I don’t say anything. But I feel something shift inside me. Not peace. Not hope. But *clarity*. Like I’ve finally stopped running and started listening.

The next thing I know, I’m walking again. The city hums around me. I don’t know if I’ll find a place to stay. I don’t know if I’ll ever feel safe. But for the first time in days, I don’t feel like I’m hiding.

I don’t know if I’m safe. I don’t know if I’m seen. But I know this: I’m not alone.

And that’s more than I’ve ever had before.

individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]
The piece follows the prompt’s basic requirements: Taylor’s first day in New Orleans, meeting another runaway, first-person voice, internal monologue, mixed tense. However, the execution is thin. Taylor’s voice oscillates between authentically raw teen sarcasm and generic YA uplift; the diction is repetitive (“regret,” “safe,” “supposed to be”) and the imagery leans on clichés (“sky painted in shades of purple and gold,” “music that sounds like it’s crying”). The new character is sketched in one stroke—red scarf, faceless drawings, Atlanta origin—and functions more as a sounding board than a person. Their dialogue is interchangeable self-disclosure: “I couldn’t breathe in that house,” “I feel like that too,” lines that announce emotion rather than reveal it through behavior or subtext. Nothing actually happens: they walk, receive free coffee, sit on a curb, exchange therapeutic platitudes. The stakes that felt urgent in the prompt—trans identity freshly rejected, penniless, alone in a strange city—are declared rather than dramatized. The backpack strap that “keeps slipping” is intended as a motif but never tied to anything concrete; it simply reappears whenever the text needs a symbolic nudge. The ending’s “clarity” and “I’m not alone” arrive without any causal event; they feel mandated by YA convention rather than earned by experience. Technically the prose is clean, but it’s also bloodless: no sensory specificity (what does wet-pavement-regret actually smell or taste like?), no surprising observations, no rhythmic variation in the sentences. The result reads like an early-draft scene that hasn’t yet discovered what its characters want from each other or from the city.

individual_results.base_prompt:
Whalepunk fantasy
The Morska Conspiracy
The Morska thieves guild experiences a sudden power vacuum as its leader was arrested in a raid in the early hours of the morning. Aya, a young woman born into aristocracy, has a keen interest in both the sciences and the arcane, having inherited her mother's gift for immateria magick (an outlawed practice for which her mother was, regrettably, hanged by the neck). Aya, bored with the world of aristocracy, has been spending her nights moonlighting with this very guild (masked, naturally). Leveraging her latent ability to summon dark entities from the immateria, she quickly rose through the ranks of the guild. Now, recognising the opportunity of the sudden power vacuum, Aya and her close companions Katra and Simeon, make a play for heart of the guild's claim to power: an ancient scythan artifact, under guard of spell and key in the depths of the guild hq. In contrast with the desperate chaos they had navigated thus far, the entrance to the underhold felt suddenly too quiet. Aya braces herself and reaches for the door.

Write the next scene as the trio enter the underhold and find themselves confronted by none other than the guild leader herself, decidedly *un*-incarcerated, and in possession of both weapons and bodyguards.

Paint a vivid picture of of the confrontation. Story beats: Aya is captured and unmasked. The trio are captured. Aya attempts to stall their demise by negotiating on her value as a hostage -- as she grapples with the inevitable consequences of her role in the guild being brought to light. Incorporate dialogue in the authentic voices of the characters. Do not write a fight scene. Lean into the gritty Victorian aesthetic with the dialogue & worldbuilding, as well as elements of gothic horror. In this world, men trust brass and oil and steel; magicka is feared and barely understood. Write in third person past tense, incorporating both Aya's internal monologue, and a heavy dialogue component. <SEED> 1000 words.
individual_results.model_response:
The iron door groaned open, not with a shriek, but with the slow, wet sigh of a thing that had long forgotten breath. Aya stepped through, the cold stone floor biting into her boots. The air inside the underhold was thick—not with dust, but with the scent of wet wool, old oil, and something beneath it: the metallic tang of forgotten blood. The silence was unnatural. Not the quiet of a vaulted chamber, but the hush of a tomb that had been sealed too soon. Above, the vaulted ceiling bore no torches, only a single, cracked skylight that let in a sickly, grey light, like the eye of a dying star.

Katra clutched her brass-handled dagger tighter, knuckles white. Simeon adjusted the worn leather of his coat, his fingers twitching toward the small, oil-slicked revolver tucked into his waistband. They had come prepared for ghosts, for traps, for the echo of a thousand stolen secrets. But this—this was not a trap. This was a reckoning.

And then she saw her.

Standing at the far end of the chamber, silhouetted against the grey light, was the guild’s leader—*Morska’s* leader. Not a woman in a mask, but one in a coat of blackened leather, stitched with silver thread that seemed to ripple like water in the dim. Her hair was pinned back with a brass clasp shaped like a shark’s jaw. Her eyes, wide and pale, reflected nothing—not the torchlight, not the shadows—but the hollows of something older, deeper. She wore a silver blade at her hip, and two men in dark cloaks stood behind her, their faces hidden beneath hoods lined with oil-stained lace.

Aya froze. Her breath caught in her throat.

*She’s alive.*

Not just alive—*unhinged*. The woman who had been arrested, who had vanished from the city’s records, who had been whispered to have drowned in the Morska River… was standing here, unscathed, unbroken. And she wore the guild’s insignia on her collar: a spiral of teeth, the mark of the first thieves.

“Ah,” the leader said, her voice like dry leaves scraping stone. “You’ve come to claim what’s ours. Or perhaps… to *reclaim* it?”

Aya’s hands trembled. She hadn’t meant to be seen. Not like this. Not unmasked. She’d worn the guild’s mask for months—its silvered visage, its carved face of a drowned sailor. But now, the mask was gone. Her face, pale and sharp with the ghost of a moonlit stare, was bare. The truth of her bloodline, her mother’s punishment, her forbidden magic—*all of it*—was laid bare in the silence.

“You shouldn’t have come,” the leader said, stepping forward. Her boots clicked on the stone, a sound that echoed too loudly in the stillness. “You were never meant to be here. Not with your kind.”

Aya’s heart hammered against her ribs. *She knows. She knows I’m a witch.*

“I didn’t come to steal,” Aya said, voice low, trembling. “I came to *save* the guild. The artifact—it’s not a weapon. It’s a key. A key to something beneath the sea. Something that remembers what we’ve buried.”

The leader tilted her head, a slow, predatory motion. “You speak as if you understand the weight of what lies in that chamber. But you don’t. You only *feel* it. Like a child who touches a flame.”

Simeon stepped forward, his voice sharp. “We didn’t come for the artifact. We came for justice. The raid—your arrest—it was a lie. You were never in custody. You were *fleeing*. And we saw you. We saw the way you moved through the fog.”

The leader laughed—a sound like a bell struck underwater. “Justice? You think the city cares about justice? It cares about *order*. And order requires silence. And silence requires *control*.”

Katra stepped forward, her voice cold. “You betrayed us. You betrayed the guild. You let them take your place. You let *her* take your name.”

The leader’s eyes narrowed. “You don’t know who I am. You don’t know the price of power. And you don’t know what I *did* to the ones who tried to stop me.”

Aya felt the cold seep into her bones. She looked down at her hands—her fingers, once so skilled in summoning the dark from the immateria, now trembling like leaves in a storm. *They know. They know I’m not just a thief. I’m a conduit. A vessel. And they will burn me for it.*

“I’m not a threat,” Aya said, her voice cracking. “I’m not a criminal. I’m just… trying to survive. My mother was hanged for *magic*. For *immateria*. You don’t understand—what I can do. What I *am*.”

The leader stepped closer, her blade glinting in the dim light. “Then let me tell you something, child. Magic isn’t power. It’s *sickness*. It’s the rot beneath the city’s skin. And you? You’re a symptom. A flaw in the system.”

Aya’s breath caught. “Then why did you let me in? Why did you let me rise?”

The leader smiled—a slow, cruel thing. “Because you *wanted* to be found. Because you *wanted* to be seen. Because you thought you could hide behind a mask, behind a lie, behind a name. But the truth? The truth is always in the shadows. And shadows don’t forgive.”

She reached out, not with violence, but with a quiet, terrifying calm. “I’ll let you live. But only as a *hostage*. You will stay here. You will speak only when spoken to. And when the city learns of your bloodline—when the Council finds out about the immateria—*you will be burned*. Not for theft. Not for rebellion. For *heresy*.”

Aya’s chest tightened. “I don’t care about the Council. I care about what I can do. I can open doors. I can summon things that *shouldn’t be*. I can—”

“You can *break* them,” the leader finished. “And that is why I want you. Not as a thief. Not as a rebel. But as a *warning*. A living proof that the old magic still walks.”

Simeon stepped forward, voice low. “We’re not going to let you do this.”

The leader turned her head, and for the first time, her gaze didn’t hold fear. It held *recognition*. “You don’t understand,” she whispered. “The artifact isn’t just a key. It’s a *mirror*. And you—*you* are the one who will see what lies behind it.”

Outside, the foghorn sounded—three long, mournful blasts. The sound echoed through the city, a call from the sea, a warning from the dead.

Aya closed her eyes. She thought of her mother, hanged in the square, her hands clutching a scrap of parchment with a sigil drawn in blood. She thought of the dark things she had summoned—shadows that spoke in tongues no one could understand, creatures that lived in the cracks between worlds.

She opened her eyes.

“I’ll talk,” Aya said, her voice barely above a whisper. “But only if you promise me one thing. That I won’t be burned. That I won’t be erased.”

The leader studied her, then slowly lowered her blade. “You have no power,” she said. “Only fear. And fear is the only currency left in this city.”

Aya nodded. “Then I’ll trade my fear for your silence.”

The silence stretched. Thick. Unbroken.

And in the stillness, the foghorn sounded once more—three times. The sea breathed. The city waited. And somewhere, beneath the stone, the artifact stirred. Waiting. Watching. Listening.

individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]
The piece nails the prompt’s required beats: the trio enter the under-hold, the supposedly imprisoned guild-leader is waiting, Aya is unmasked, all three are captured, and Aya bargains for her life by leveraging her forbidden magic. The Victorian-gothic texture is present in every paragraph—wet wool, brass clasps, oil-slick revolvers, foghorns, sigils drawn in blood—so the world-building feels continuous with the prompt. Dialogue is plentiful and mostly in-period; characters speak with the terse, slightly elevated diction of gas-lamp gutter royalty. Internal monologue is woven through Aya’s reactions, keeping her POV central.

However, the scene is more tableau than drama. Once the leader speaks, the tempo stalls: we get a succession of ornate speeches that re-state stakes we already grasp (magic is feared, Aya is valuable, the artifact is dangerous). The leader’s diction drifts toward abstract menace (“magic is sickness… you are a symptom… shadows don’t forgive”) without revealing concrete new information or escalating the conflict. Aya’s negotiation—her one tactical move—arrives in a single line (“I’ll trade my fear for your silence”) that the leader accepts with no visible cost or counter-demand, so the tension deflates rather than twists. The bodyguards never speak or move; Katra and Simeon interject once each but otherwise vanish, so the capture feels administrative rather than earned. The final paragraph gestures toward a larger, darker game, but because the characters have not materially changed their positions the ending reads as a graceful fade-out instead of a hinge-point.

Stylistically the prose is lush—sometimes to a fault. Phrases like “the hush of a tomb that had been sealed too soon” or “a sound like a bell struck underwater” are evocative, but they pile up so thickly that description begins to smother action. Sentence rhythm is generally fluid, yet frequent em-dash pauses and appended clauses create a narcotic cadence that undercuts urgency. The piece never becomes purple in the “livid amethyst heavens” sense, but it skirts overwrought because every object and breath is freighted with gothic weight; we rarely get a plain detail to anchor the fantastic.

Characterization is thin beneath the varnish. Aya’s fear and maternal trauma are reiterated, but she makes no surprising choices; her bargaining chip (I can summon things) is exactly the power the prompt already told us she has. The leader is a poised, cryptic villainess straight from central casting—no flicker of doubt, personal history, or visible motive beyond “control.” Katra and Simeon are present only to be disarmed. Because no one reveals a hidden goal or shifts emotional ground, the scene feels static: a beautifully lit photograph of a stand-off rather than a living confrontation.

In short, the response fulfills the prompt’s externals but fails to dramatize the power struggle it depicts; the dialogue is plentiful yet circular, and the descriptive excess, while atmospheric, muffles narrative drive.

The Morska Conspiracy

individual_results.model_response:
The air in the underhold was thick with the scent of damp stone and something older—something that curled in the back of Aya’s throat like smoke. The gas lamps, their flames trembling in the cold, cast long, jagged shadows across the vaulted ceiling, stretching like fingers across the slick black stone. The silence was not peaceful. It was *listening*. Aya’s breath hitched as she stepped through the final archway, the brass key clutched in her fist, her fingers slick with sweat. Katra, her eyes wide behind her cracked spectacles, pressed a hand to the wall, her knuckles white. Simeon, ever the pragmatist, adjusted his oilskin coat with a grim frown.

They had come for the Scythan Key—a relic said to open the gates to the drowned city of Vortha, a place where time folded and the dead walked with purpose. The guild had whispered of it for generations. Aya had only ever heard the stories, but now, standing in this subterranean chamber, the weight of the artifact pressed upon her like a stone chest.

Then, the light shifted.

From the far end of the chamber, a figure stepped forward. Tall, draped in a cloak of deep indigo that seemed to drink the light, she moved with the grace of a predator. Her face was pale, sharp, and unyielding—familiar in a way that made Aya’s blood run cold. *Mira Vael*, the guild’s former leader, the woman who had been arrested, the woman who had vanished from the city records. Now, she stood before them, her hands resting on the hilt of a blade forged from a meteorite, its edge catching the gaslight like a shard of frozen starlight.

“You’re late,” Mira said, her voice smooth as oil, but edged with something colder—calcified resolve. “I thought you’d have been dead by now.”

Aya’s pulse roared in her ears. *She knew.* The raid had been a ruse. A trap. The arrest had been staged to create chaos, to lure the real leaders into the open. And now, Mira stood here, unharmed, unbroken, and utterly in control.

“No,” Aya whispered, her voice trembling. “I wasn’t supposed to come. I didn’t even know—”

“You *knew*,” Mira cut in, stepping closer. “You knew the truth about your mother. You knew what she did. And you did it again. You summoned the *Vorlag* from the immateria. You brought them here. You *broke* the seal.”

Aya’s breath caught. *The Vorlag.* The dark entities from the forbidden layers beneath the world. Her mother had done it once. Aya had done it again—just once, to open a passage to the old vaults. But now, it was clear: the artifact wasn’t just a key. It was a *door*. And Mira had known. She had *watched*.

“You’re not supposed to be alive,” Aya said, her voice cracking. “They said you were hanged by the neck. That you were gone.”

Mira smiled, a thin, cruel thing. “I was. But I didn’t die. I *changed*.” She lifted her hand, and a small flame flickered in the air—not from a lantern, but from the very air itself. “The immateria doesn’t kill. It *transforms*. And I am no longer just a thief. I am a guardian of what was lost.”

Katra stepped forward, her voice sharp. “You can’t just take her. She’s a hostage. The guild’s laws say—”

Mira’s eyes narrowed. “Laws? The laws of men are brittle. The laws of the *immateria* are eternal. And I have the power to make them obey.” She turned to Aya. “You were born to this. Your mother died because she refused to obey. You will die because you *choose* to disobey.”

Aya’s hands trembled. She thought of her mother’s final words—*“The dark is not evil. It is only forgotten.”* She thought of the cold whispers in the vaults, the way the stones seemed to breathe. She had not meant to bring the Vorlag here. She had only wanted to *see* what lay beneath. But now, Mira stood before her, not as a prisoner, but as a *truth-teller*.

“I will not fight,” Aya said, her voice low, steady. “But I will bargain.”

Mira tilted her head. “Bargain?”

“I am worth more than you think,” Aya said, stepping forward despite the cold steel at her back. “I know the secrets of the immateria. I can open the gates again. I can *control* the Vorlag. And if you let me live—*if you let me go*—you will have a weapon. A tool. One that will never betray you.”

Mira’s lips curled. “You speak as if you are offering me salvation.”

“I am offering you *power*,” Aya said. “I can give you access to the drowned city. I can show you how to walk through time. But only if you let me go. Only if you *let me live*.”

Silence fell again. The gas lamps flickered. Shadows danced across the walls like restless spirits.

“You have no idea what you’re asking,” Mira said finally. “The immateria is not a tool. It is a *memory*. And memories are not for sale.”

“But I can *protect* you,” Aya pleaded. “I can keep the Vorlag at bay. I can stop them from rising. And if you give me a chance—*one chance*—I will not bring them back.”

Katra stepped forward, her voice trembling. “Aya, stop. This isn’t how it ends. You’re not a weapon. You’re a girl. A girl with a mother who died for her beliefs.”

Mira looked at Katra, then at Simeon, who stood frozen, his hands clenched at his sides. “You are all fools,” she said. “You think the world needs heroes? It needs *balance*. And I have it.”

She reached out, her fingers brushing Aya’s cheek. “You will not survive this. But you will *remember*. And when the world forgets, when the laws fall, when the brass and steel crumble—*you will be the one who remembers what was lost*.”

Aya felt the cold seep into her bones. She felt the weight of her mother’s ghost, the whisper of the Vorlag in her veins. She had not come to steal the key. She had come to *understand* it. And now, in this dark chamber, with the gaslight flickering like a dying breath, she realized: she had never been a thief. She had only been a vessel.

Mira turned, her cloak swirling like smoke. “Come with me,” she said. “We will go deeper. We will find what lies beneath the city. And when the time comes, you will *know* what it means to be truly powerful.”

Aya did not move. She could not. Her mask had slipped—her face, pale and trembling, exposed to the cold light. The truth was no longer hidden. The immateria had claimed her. And now, it claimed her *again*.

She closed her eyes. The silence pressed in. The world beyond the vaults was still. And somewhere, deep in the drowned city, the Vorlag stirred. Waiting. Listening.

And Aya, for the first time, felt like she belonged.
